thread.title_full: Tottenham to consult FA and police over Millwall ticket allocation amid fears of crowd trouble

author: Matt Law
title: Tottenham to consult FA and police over Millwall ticket allocation amid fears of crowd trouble
text:
Tottenham to consult FA and police over Millwall ticket allocation amid fears of crowd trouble Three Millwall fans were arrested after the pitch invasion following the win over Leicester Matt Law , Football News Correspondent  30pm 
T ottenham Hotspur will hold talks with their local Safety Advisory Group and the Football Association before any decision is taken on how many tickets Millwall receive for the FA Cup quarter-final tie between the clubs amid fears of trouble. 
The move came as Leicester City complained to the FA over the “abuse, provocation and intimidation” their fans suffered in the Cup defeat at Millwall on Saturday as home fans ran on to the pitch to celebrate the League One club’s victory. 
The draw for the last eight has rekindled memories of the last time Spurs met Millwall in a pre-season ‘friendly’ in 2001, when the two sets of fans fought running battles. 
Other than violence erupting before and after the game at the New Den, there were reports of a group of Tottenham fans attacking the Caulkers Pub in Bermondsey. It was claimed that 30 police officers and three police horses were injured during the day, with one man being taken to hospital with knife wounds. 
Some of the violent scenes can be witnessed on YouTube, with one comment reading: “Ever since that day every cup draw been wanting Tottenham away.” Spurs and Millwall last met at Keith Stevens' testimonial in 2001, a match marred by violence before and after the game Credit: Action Images 
T he FA is well aware of the history between the clubs and will be involved in talks over the kick-off time with the Metropolitan Police, Tottenham, Millwall and, if the tie is picked for television, broadcasters. 
FA Cup rules allow for an away allocation of up to 15 per cent of the home stadium, although that number is subject to approval from the local Safety Advisory Group, which is made up of the police, council, fire brigade and club. 
Because of the work on the new stadium, the capacity of White Hart Lane has been reduced to 31,500 this season, which could also have an impact on the number of tickets allocated to Millwall. 
The tie is likely to be the last-ever FA Cup game at White Hart Lane, as the semi-finals and final are staged at Wembley and Spurs are due to move into the national stadium for all games next season while their new home is finished. 
M eanwhile, the fallout from unruly scenes at the Den after the defeat of Leicester continued with the Premier League champions saying they received “numerous complaints” and “will not accept the safety of our supporters, players, and staff being compromised”. 
A Leicester spokesman added: “Following receipt of numerous complaints relating to the constant abuse, provocation and intimidation of our players, staff and supporters from our arrival at the stadium, throughout the match and in its immediate aftermath, we have registered our dissatisfaction with the FA. ” 
A Millwall spokesman said: “We have been made aware of these allegations today and are extremely disappointed that Leicester City, as is the professional protocol in such instances, did not raise them on the day of the game itself.” The FA said it would contact Leicester to discuss the issues. 
The quarter-final will put Tottenham star Harry Kane up against the club he spent six months on loan with, which was enough time for the striker to be named Millwall’s young player of the season after scoring nine goals. 
Kane believes Spurs will have an advantage in this season’s FA Cup if they get past Gent in the Europa League at Wembley on Thursday night and knock out Millwall to reach the last four. Kane (left) says Tottenham can benefit from having played European games at Wembley this season Credit: Rex Features 
A sked if the fact Tottenham have played Champions League and Europa League games at Wembley can be an advantage should they progress to the semi-finals of the FA Cup, Kane replied: “Yeah, 100 per cent, that’s important. 
“We had a little taste for it in the Champions League, we won our last game we played there. We go again on Thursday and if we can get a good feeling there, get used to it, play our style of football, then the more games we play there the better it will be for us, the more used to the surroundings we’ll be. We’ve got to try to make Wembley our home.”
